stem: A 28-year-old is brought to the ER with pinpoint pupils, respirations of 6/min, and shallow breathing. He is unresponsive to painful stimuli. Complete the bowtie to manage this opioid overdose.

actions.text: Provide ventilatory support with a bag-valve-mask (BVM)

rationale.correct: Pinpoint pupils + severe bradypnea = Opioid Toxicity. Priority is reversing respiratory depression (Naloxone) and maintaining oxygenation (BVM). Monitoring Focus: Respiratory status and consciousness.
rationale.incorrect: Flumazenil is for benzos. Atropine is for symptomatic bradycardia but won't fix the underlying respiratory drive failure in overdose.
clinicalPearls: Naloxone has a shorter half-life than many opioids; the client may slip back into respiratory depression after the first dose wears off.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking Narcan is the ONLY priority
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Oxygenation/Ventilation is ALWAYS the priority in a client who isn't breathing effectively, even before the antidote.
